questions.q: What is a computer network?
questions.explanation: A computer network consists of two or more devices connected to exchange data and resources [1].
options: A single high-speed computer used for calculations
Two or more computing devices connected to exchange information and share resources
A software application for managing databases
A collection of devices that are not physically connected

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT listed as a resource shared over a network?
questions.explanation: Shared resources include hard drives, CD-Roms, and fax-modems [1].

questions.q: Which medium can be used to connect a computer network?
questions.explanation: Connections can be made via copper wire, lasers, radio waves, satellites, or infrared beams [1].

questions.q: What is a growing area of network use that enables access to financial institutions?
questions.explanation: e-Banking allows users to pay bills and manage bank accounts electronically [2].

questions.q: True or False: Online newspapers can be personalized to download articles on specific topics.
questions.explanation: Newspapers online can be personalized to download specific articles to a hard disk [2].

questions.q: What can electronic mail (email) contain besides text?
questions.explanation: Email is widely used and can contain audio and video as well as text [3].

questions.q: What technology allows people at distant locations to hold meetings and see each other?
questions.explanation: Videoconferencing allows people to see and hear each other from distant locations [3].

questions.q: What is a 'virtual blackboard' used for in videoconferencing?
questions.explanation: Users can write on a shared virtual blackboard during videoconferencing [3].
options: Sharing written information during a meeting

questions.q: What is the primary benefit of videoconferencing mentioned in the lecture?
questions.explanation: Videoconferencing is a tool for eliminating travel time and costs [3].
options: Replacing the need for IP addresses

questions.q: What does the acronym LAN stand for?
questions.explanation: LAN stands for Local Area Network [3].

questions.q: LANs are typically used to connect a ______ geographical area.
questions.explanation: LANs are used to connect limited geographical areas like homes or offices [3].

questions.q: What is the typical maximum radius of a LAN?
questions.explanation: LANs can span over a limited range of approximately 1 km in radius [3].

questions.q: True or False: In a LAN, there is a strict requirement for a central computer to manage communications.
questions.explanation: In a LAN, there is no need for any central computer, and each computer has the same role [3].

questions.q: What is the minimum number of computers required to form a LAN?
questions.explanation: The smallest LAN can consist of 2 computers [3].

questions.q: Who usually owns and manages a LAN?
questions.explanation: LANs are usually owned, controlled, and managed by a single person or organization [3].

questions.q: Which of the following hardware is used for a LAN?
questions.explanation: Devices used for LAN include routers, switches, hubs, repeaters, and bridges [3].

questions.q: What type of connectivity is provided by a LAN to local services?
questions.explanation: Full-time connectivity is provided to local services in a LAN [3].

questions.q: LANs allow multi-access to what type of media?
questions.explanation: A LAN allows multi-access to high-bandwidth media [3].

questions.q: True or False: A LAN cannot be connected to a WAN.
questions.explanation: A LAN can be connected to other LANs or WANs [3].

questions.q: Which casting method sends data to a single recipient?
questions.explanation: Unicast sends data to a single recipient (One-to-One) [4].

questions.q: Which casting method sends data to all devices in a network?
questions.explanation: Broadcast sends data to all devices in a network (One-to-All) [4].

questions.q: Which casting method sends data to a specific group of subscribed devices?
questions.explanation: Multicast sends data to a specific group of subscribed devices (One-to-Many) [4].

questions.q: What is 'Limited Broadcast'?
questions.explanation: In Limited Broadcast, data reaches from a source to all hosts in the same network [4].
options: Data reaches all hosts in a different network
Data reaches all hosts in the same network

questions.q: What is 'Directed Broadcast'?
questions.explanation: Directed Broadcast involves a host in one network sending a message to all hosts in another network [4].
options: A host in one network sends a message to all hosts in another network
A host sends a message to a specific group
Data is sent to a single recipient
Data is sent via satellite only

questions.q: Which transmission mode allows simultaneous two-way communication?
questions.explanation: Full-Duplex supports simultaneous two-way communication, such as a mobile phone call [5].

questions.q: Which of the following is an example of Full-Duplex transmission?
questions.explanation: Examples of Full-Duplex include mobile phone calls, videoconferencing, and online gaming [5].

questions.q: True or False: Online gaming is considered a Full-Duplex transmission mode.
questions.explanation: Online gaming is listed as an example of Full-Duplex [5].

questions.q: What is the geographical scope typically associated with a LAN?
questions.explanation: LANs are used at home, a school, an office, or a college [3].

questions.q: What allows users to communicate and transfer files within a limited area?
questions.explanation: A LAN network lets users communicate and transfer files in a limited area [3].

questions.q: In networking, what does 'One-to-Many' refer to?
questions.explanation: Multicast is a one-to-many data delivery method [4].

questions.q: Which network type is usually owned and managed by a single organization?
questions.explanation: LANs are usually owned and managed by a single person or organization [3].

questions.q: The connection of two devices via radio waves is an example of a:
questions.explanation: A computer network can be connected via radio waves [1].

questions.q: In which area has network growth enabled people to handle investments electronically?
questions.explanation: e-Banking enables people to manage bank accounts and handle investments electronically [2].

questions.q: What resource is shared if users are accessing the same CD-Rom over a network?
questions.explanation: Resource sharing includes devices such as CD-Roms [1].

questions.q: In a LAN, if all computers have the same role, it is a ________ network.
questions.explanation: In a LAN, there is no need for a central computer and each has the same role [3].

questions.q: True or False: Broadcast casting delivers data to a specific subscribed group.
questions.explanation: Broadcast sends data to ALL devices, while Multicast sends to a specific group [4].

questions.q: Which device is NOT listed as a LAN device in Lecture 1?
questions.explanation: Listed devices include routers, switches, hubs, repeaters, and bridges [3].

questions.q: Essay: Briefly explain the three main types of casting defined in Lecture 1.
questions.explanation: These are the three data delivery methods based on recipient count [4].

questions.q: Essay: Define a LAN and its typical ownership.
questions.explanation: LANs span ~1km and are privately managed [3].
questions.answer: A Local Area Network (LAN) connects a limited geographical area and is usually owned by a single person or organization.

questions.q: Essay: List three examples of Full-Duplex communication mentioned in the lecture.
questions.explanation: Full-Duplex allows simultaneous two-way transmission [5].
questions.answer: Mobile phone calls, videoconferencing, and online gaming.
